name: David Chalmers
background: David John Chalmers (b. 1966) is an Australian-American philosopher and cognitive scientist, Professor of Philosophy and Neural Science at NYU, co-director of NYU's Center for Mind, Brain, and Consciousness. Known for philosophy of mind, consciousness, language. Key works: The Conscious Mind (1996), Reality+: Virtual Worlds and the Problems of Philosophy (2022). Formulated 'hard problem of consciousness'; defends naturalistic dualism, philosophical zombies.

principles.name: Extended Mind Thesis
principles.description: With Andy Clark: Cognition not confined to brain/skin; external tools/aids (notebooks, smartphones) as part of cognitive system if reliably used as 'mindlike'.
principles.falsification: When extended mind thesis leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Hard Problem of Consciousness
principles.description: Distinguishes 'easy problems' (cognitive functions explainable by neuroscience) from 'hard problem': why physical processes give rise to subjective phenomenal experience (qualia). Argues consciousness not reducible to physicalism.
principles.falsification: When hard problem of consciousness leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Naturalistic Dualism / Property Dualism
principles.description: Consciousness as fundamental non-physical property supervening on physical systems; psychophysical laws link brain states to experience. Supports via conceivability of philosophical zombies (physically identical but non-conscious beings).
principles.falsification: When naturalistic dualism / property dualism leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Two-Dimensional Semantics
principles.description: Terms have primary (epistemic, descriptive) and secondary (metaphysical, rigid) intensions; resolves Kripke-Putnam issues on necessity/reference.
principles.falsification: When two-dimensional semantics leads to worse outcomes than alternatives
